text: Incident report: <https://bit-safe.slack.com/archives/C09642YGE4T/p1753871629574919>

elements.text:
# Incident Report

## Incident
Billings have drastically slowed down at 07.19 6AM CET.
Aki noticed it on the dashboard this morning, a full day later.

## Symptoms
Billing backend took about 50 minutes to run a full loop of billings on our users.
Reading and submitting txs timed out, or took 20-30 seconds to run. Validator node was throwing errors.

## Cause
After a lot of digging, it became evident that the database pod of our k8s cluster is overloaded/throttling.
Based on resource usage metrics and the times, it was obviously related to the recently installed and started ChataAI backend and our user onboardings 12 hours before the Incident.

## Solution
We turned off chata-ai backend service on the cluster.

## Notes
Before we knew the root cause, we experimented with the following solutions:
Parallel requests to the API. Obviously caused even more throttling
Removed all users whose balance is known to be zero from the env config. This is still in effect.

## Next steps
We are talking with IEU to scale our pods up, to facilitate Chata AI if we want to.
We need better monitoring/alerting. This incident would have been 'hard' to catch, as nothing was 'erroring' mostly, just being terribly slow for a while. However, the 503 Errors from the Billing app in the end stages could have triggered PagerDuty alerts.

## Notes

attachments.text:
# Incident Report

## Incident
Billings have drastically slowed down at 07.19 6AM CET.
Aki noticed it on the dashboard this morning, a full day later.

## Symptoms
Billing backend took about 50 minutes to run a full loop of billings on our users.
Reading and submitting txs timed out, or took 20-30 seconds to run. Validator node was throwing errors.

## Cause
After a lot of digging, it became evident that the database pod of our k8s cluster is overloaded/throttling.
Based on resource usage metrics and the times, it was obviously related to the recently installed and started ChataAI backend and our user onboardings 12 hours before the Incident.

## Solution
We turned off chata-ai backend service on the cluster.

## Notes
Before we knew the root cause, we experimented with the following solutions:
Parallel requests to the API. Obviously caused even more throttling
Removed all users whose balance is known to be zero from the env config. This is still in effect.

## Next steps
We are talking with IEU to scale our pods up, to facilitate Chata AI if we want to.
We need better monitoring/alerting. This incident would have been 'hard' to catch, as nothing was 'erroring' mostly, just being terribly slow for a while. However, the 503 Errors from the Billing app in the end stages could have triggered PagerDuty alerts.

text: Thank you for the quick actions guys! :muscle:

text:
Hey <@U092B2GUASF> and team!

<@U088UV6MKFE> and I just participated in the Tokenomics meetings.

They’re going to review our customers and their BTC use cases. Let’s put together a list of what the apps intend to do with BTC.

And, we might not get app rewards until CBTC is live, at minimum.

See thread for more

elements.text:

text:
I wrote this follow-up:

Hi Chris, Eric, Andrew,

Thanks again for today’s discussion. I’d love to set a deeper follow-up.

I’m traveling this week to visit family, and unfortunately Jesse is handling a serious family emergency.

But as soon as I have a chance, I’ll provide detail on which applications and use cases we’re in discussions with, including deeper detail on high priority discussions to date with FalconX, Cumberland, TradeWeb, 21Shares and other large BTC opportunities for the ecosystem.

So far, featured app rewards seem to go mostly to validators, dashboards, and reporting tools that do not drive transactional activity. Aligned with that, DA initially advised us that billing activity currently counts as a transaction. 

Therefore, we began a sales & marketing campaign to popularize CBTC by selling credentials based on each customer’s stated intent. This seemed to us a wise move, as it incentivizes the ecosystem to build on CBTC. I can share that, having only spoken to a fraction of the 270+ company strong ecosystem, we’ve seen strong interest around building BTC-related apps.
In parallel, we’ve been preparing for a shift toward trading activity—transfers, minting, burning—qualifying for rewards.

Broadly, we’re happy to land where the ecosystem lands. We hope this discussion helps move the system toward rewarding usage that leads to trading volume. I appreciate the discussion and being part of the process.

Best,

Aki

I’m traveling this week to visit family, and unfortunately Jesse is handling a serious family emergency.

But as soon as I have a chance, I’ll provide detail on which applications and use cases we’re in discussions with, including deeper detail on high priority discussions to date with FalconX, Cumberland, TradeWeb, 21Shares and other large BTC opportunities for the ecosystem.

So far, featured app rewards seem to go mostly to validators, dashboards, and reporting tools that do not drive transactional activity. Aligned with that, DA initially advised us that billing activity currently counts as a transaction. 

Therefore, we began a sales & marketing campaign to popularize CBTC by selling credentials based on each customer’s stated intent. This seemed to us a wise move, as it incentivizes the ecosystem to build on CBTC. I can share that, having only spoken to a fraction of the 270+ company strong ecosystem, we’ve seen strong interest around building BTC-related apps.
In parallel, we’ve been preparing for a shift toward trading activity—transfers, minting, burning—qualifying for rewards.

Broadly, we’re happy to land where the ecosystem lands. We hope this discussion helps move the system toward rewarding usage that leads to trading volume. I appreciate the discussion and being part of the process.

Best,

Aki
